comments.commentBody: This is a great article, and getting the perspective of other professional athletes was really interesting.  I started watching NBA at the tail-end of Magic/Bird era, so for me the gold-standard is Michael Jordan.  As a Knicks and Nets fan I didn't like MJ, but he was the greatest of his era, and I couldn't help admiring his game and character.  Lebron is an awesome talent and maybe the best player ever, but when he declares he is the best player, or he puts on an espn show to declare his playing intentions, he shows a fragility of ego, self-absorption, desire for celebrity, mental weakness...not sure exactly what, that MJ would never show.  Lebron reminds me more of Shaq than Jordan, which is fine because Shaq was awesome and he seemed to enjoy playing and celebrity.  MJ on the other hand, valued winning over all those other things, and he trusted his team (over time) and elevated everyone.  Lebron doesn't have Pippen equivalent, but Mozgov, Shumpert, Smith, and Thomas vs Longley, Grant, Paxson, Armstrong, Harper might favor Cleveland.
I agree with LeBron's self assessment: He is the best B'baller in the world. However, he is sitting at home while the Warriors are the team having the parade. A little humility never hurt anyone.

LeBron's strength and confidence reads as arrogant to some.  In a news conference in the middle of the Playoffs with everything on the line did anyone think he was going to show doubt or fear?  He sees himself as a role model for his team and nothing but total confidence in his every word and action will inspire.  Le Bron saying what hundreds of news articles and broadcasters have been saying about him for months, even years " best basketball player in the world" gets him in trouble.   Really people?  He is what he says he is and he proved it all year long and especially in the Playoffs.   Go fight about all the other things you fight about and just give him his due.  He has earned it.  If other NBA stars take offense, fine.  These players can prove their worth through their actions like he does.  That works for them, their team and their fans.   Spouting of out of jealousy or hate serves no one including the speaker.

i don't get how football is the ultimate team sport. basketball and hockey both have players playing offence and defence with switches coming in a split second. I will say I can't imagine a hockey player boasting like james did about being the best in the world.

I agree about Russell. he won at every level. state high school championship, ncaa champion, Olympic champion and 12 final appearances with 11 championships in a 13 year nba career. gobsmacks me how rarely he's mentioned. I guess anything that happened in black and white doesn't count.

the most competitive league in the world has to be in the usa because it's the usa. I wonder how many soccer leagues were studied at or how about aussie rules football, rugby.....? American hyperbole at its most normal......
The only thing Russell is not qualified to tell James re his loss is, "I know how you feel."

Correct: Humility and modesty are essential ingredients to ensure long-lasting superstar status......Look at team dynasty eras where these qualities dominated: Pittsburgh Steelers, SF 49ers, GB Packers
(1960s), to name just three.

All are the epitomy of bark less, play harder (without fanfare and self-boasting).

Yes, James is the best in the world, but others should exclaim....NOT him.
True, his shooting percentage in the Finals was not exactly stellar.....and it was poor in the 4th quarter in Game #6 vs. Golden State, especially at crunch time.

Smith is a notorious streak shooter.  He got hot down the stretch... but by your brilliant logic, James should have taken the ball from Smith and put up the shots himself... to prove to you that he's "clutch."  Ridiculous.  Then the critics would have called him selfish. He can do nothing right.

The games I watched James did take the ball from everyone but didn't make very many.   Maybe if he hadn't missed all those Lebron Rules free throws he got (when he commits the foul but gets to shoot two), JR's clutch three's at the end might have been enough to force overtime.   James was playing hero ball -- just enough to look great but not enough for JR's spectacular three's to make the difference.   He gave up way before JR took over and almost wrote a different ending.  Don't like Smith's persona much but in those final few minutes his three's revealed the emperor's new clothes.

He is undoubtedly a great player, but I'm not so sure that he's the greatest clutch player.  Who was making the wild 3's during the 4th quarter comeback in game 6? J.R. Smith, not LeBron James.  James missed an awful lot of shots in that 4th quarter, which didn't help their comeback attempt at all.  It was almost as if he was spent and done.  He always has great overall game statistics, but does he make the big 3 in the crucial situations?
So trivial it's worth noting?  Understand.  The knicks are your team and in the NBA that's the definition of triviality...a tempest in search of a teacup.
Tempest...meet teacup.  This defines triviality.

But was Jackson's influence on the nation a positive one?  Populism, closing the 2nd Bank of the United States, the whole massacre of native Americans - None of these were positive developments. The US would not issue a national currency until the Lincoln Admin. The nation's economy fared less well after the loss of a central bank. This would create a crisis for the management of govt debt and govt payments during the civil was such that Lincoln's treasury secretary would need to create a nominal central banking infrastructure to meet the govt's need.

I have a question that I hope someone would answer for me. It is why do some people hate people of other races? I have searched my soul, and the strongest negative emotion I have ever experienced toward someone else is anger. Never hatred. I am here in Australia with my half white half black children. My wife is a white woman from Wyoming and I am a black man from South Florida raised in Sweden. I am 44 years old. I can remember in the 1980s traveling around the world without much money and meeting people at airports who would take me in for the duration of my stay. My best friend is a girl I met at a comic store in Tokyo when I turned 12 and my father put me on a flight to Japan, with instructions to not come home for a month. All I had was £100 in my pocket. We met at a comic store at Narita and we have been friends ever since. I met my wife at Broward County Library in Fort Lauderdale after arriving Florida from Stockholm in the year 2000. We have been together ever since. I spoke Swedish to her because I thought she might be Swedish due to her blonde and blue eyed look. She laughed and told me her parents came from Austria. She had just arrived in Fort Lauderdale after serving Peace Corp in Jamaica as a Civil Engineer. I told her I was born in Jamaica, but never lived there. That my father came from Nigeria. She said her boss in Jamaica was a Nigerian, and was the smartest engineer she ever met, including her time at Cornell. People have more in common than they realize.

It's amazing to hear some conservatives actually anticipate civil disobedience by blacks in Charleston as was the case in Ferguson. Almost like they think that rational thought somehow eludes blacks, and that blacks are innately violent. There is no civil disobedience in Charleston today because 1. the  racism and violence wasn't perpetrated by officers of the law 2. It wasn't being covered up by the authorities. 3. the perpetrator is rightfully on his way to facing the full weight of the justice system. These 3 reasons make Charleston a completely different situation from Ferguson and hence the difference in the reaction.

@Little Phila says: "This is not a product of our society".
I'm sorry Little Phila, but to this outside observer, and no doubt to countless others both outside and inside the USA, this atrocity is very much a product of the society that it occurred in.

In my country it took only one such horrific massacre at Port Arthur, Tasmania in 1996 to see very strict gun control introduced nation-wide by the conservative federal government of the time. I thought that after Sandy Hook the US would do something similar, but instead the reverse happened. The NRA tail has wagged the dog, and guns are even more prevalent and easy to obtain. How many more of these events can America expect before anything is done about it? Countless, apparently.

So before "virtual violence" why was America involved in mass shooting, lynching, slavery, nuclear war, racial prisons and forced relocations?
Teaching children to be less violent can never hurt, but to say one can be video gamed into murder is ridiculous. Virtual violence may expose people to certain concepts, but that person would have to posesess a particular mental state, or lack of, for it to manifest as reality. "Normal" people would never do this no matter the violence you subject them to. If not, more people would return from war to become serial killers or millions of FPS gamers that would be teabagging the corpses of the general populous right now.
He was raised to hate and look down on people of other ethnicities by insecure people. People get the all clear to dispise something from other people, not fictional situations. Instead of blaming games or tv, let's blame institutionalized racism and gun culture that demonizes and creates the fear of fellow humans all while glamorizing the power to take their life. We, as America, say it's ok to hate or be apathetic as we kill other ethnicities on a global scale. This 21 year old represents America whether we like to admit it or not.
I'm white and have been gaming most of my life. That includes fantasy RPGs, violent FPSs and the controversial GTA series. Have I ever realistically wanted to cast spells, run over, shoot or otherwise viciously murder a church full of people? I would rather die then take another's life.

I doubt he could have done as much murder with a rifle or shotgun. Automatic weapons and handguns should be outlawed in America. If he had the gall to bring a rifle or shotgun inside, which would be very doubtful, at least the Pastor or a member could have asked "whatcha gonna hunt durin' the prayer meetin' brother?" I don't say that to be funny - just to prove a point. This guy should be executed by firing squad and hear these last words: "we're sorry, but we just have to do this."
No, it's a sociopathic racist crime. Don't take the easy way out and lump this guy in with mentally ill people. ''Racism'' is not a symptom in the DSM-IV. It's a choice.

Good thing an "automatic" (They are not really automatic.) weapon was not used. If one had been, the rants here on that subject would be over the top. This is a mental illness crime, like Sandy Hook. Okay, the killer hates blacks. That does not change the fact that he is insane, and this is a mental illness issue in spite of the fact that so many of you want to use this to further your racial arguments. These things will continue, and not just against blacks, as long as the huge U.S. population and its social, economic pressures produces crazy people. Accept it and move on.

no need to end our endless wars or campaign of robot assassination or our glorification of the youth we send to murder innocent people around the world.

just disarm all citizens and thing is perfect.

Pres. Obama is right. Nowhere else in the modern world do we see such carnage day in and day out, the shame of our country. Anyone with a grudge or belief or insecurity can kill many people for no reason or any reason. The Second Amendment is today interpreted in ways that the founders of the nation never intended, or stated in the language. We need to repeal the 2nd Amendment or have the Courts return our nation to its actual meaning, word for word. It's a tall order and may take more than a generation but there is no alternative. The Amendment addresses a well organized militia, not individuals bearing arms.

From a fellow Austrian back to you: I feel exactly the same way, and I am still living in this mad gun culture. Probably not much longer. I am disgusted by the spinelessness of the politicians who are bought by the NRA and the gun lobbyists.
Nothing will ever change this strange obsession with guns here, not toddlers shooting their parents or siblings "by accident", not school mass murders, not people like Clive Bundy and his posse standing up to the Feds, fully armed to protect an illegal "right". The tragic misinterpretation and exploitation of the Second Amendment by the gun nuts will just not be questioned. Ever.

These incidents of horrific violence will continue with disturbing regularity until we control the ability of psychologically deranged males to obtain, semi-automatic rifles, handguns and ammunition. Psychologically disturbed individuals will always be with us. In order to protect innocent people from these armed marauders, we must now drastically curtail the ability of everyone to obtain arms and ammunition. If you drive a car you must have a license because you can kill people with an automobile. For that very same reason, if you require a rifle or handgun you should be required to obtain a license.

They still have the audacity to fly the confederate flag in the State Capital. Obviously, they still believe in slavery and suppression in spite of their governors words. Take down that flag forever. Allison

How can we go beyond saying "Enough is enough.? How can our elected representatives take action?  Perhaps those Senators including mine from Massachusetts can take it upon themselves to offer a bill including the  mounting of  a filibuster of mourning, a vigil on the Senate floor extended in duration,  calling on their colleagues to pass some semblance of a gun control/monitoring bill to lessen (albeit not eliminate) the mayhem so regularly inflicted on the nation.  Something, anything.

We do not need more gun control, the constitution provides the right to bear arms. The problem is how guns are handled. Senseless acts of violence such as this are possible with or without guns.

Blame needs to be shifted from the gun to the person using it. Dylan Roof is an ignorant racist and the victims deserve justice, appointed by a jury of his peers; sentenced by a judge.

My sympathy goes out to the families who lost loved ones due to another stupid act of violence. We are all one race -- human.

I honestly wish there were no guns. I have never owned one, nor do I intend to. However, many people seem reluctant to simply give up their guns.

In a perfect world things like this wouldn't happen. We wouldn't need laws or governments either.

We can enforce stricter laws, but can we eradicate guns?
Mr. Roof hardly represents the nearly 79,000 NRA annual meeting attendees in Nashville without incident, last April.

What seems clear to me is that racism, terrorism, extremism are regretably a part of our human condition and can not be eradicated. But guns, the instrument of this hate, can be.
We may not be able to change the hated, bigotry, anger and ignorance of these mad men, but we can sure take away their guns.For that we need only political will, a bit of courage, and for politicians to stop worrying about the NRA.
What we permit in the name of the 2nd Amendment is insanity.
